intro: Rhamnus infectoria var. nana, commonly known as the dwarf common buckthorn, is a shrub native to parts of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, making it a low-growing plant with dense, dark green foliage. The plant produces small, black berries that are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. It thrives in moist, shady environments and is often found in woodlands and along streambanks. Its compact form and adaptability make it a notable species in ecological studies and conservation efforts.
